think that we before have heard them told<sep>thy registers and thee i both defy<sep>not wondring at the present nor the past<sep>for thy records and what we see doth lie<sep>made more or less by thy continual haste<sep>this i do vow and this shall ever be<sep>i will be true despite thy scythe and thee<sep>~<sep>if my dear love were but the child of state<sep>it might for fortunes bastard be unfathered<sep>as subject to times love or to times hate<sep>weeds among weeds or flowers with flowers gathered<sep>no it was builded far from accident<sep>it suffers not in smiling pomp nor falls<sep>under the blow of thralled discontent<sep>whereto th inviting time our fashion calls<sep>it fears not policy that heretic<sep>which works on leases of shortnumbered hours<sep>but all alone stands hugely politic<sep>that it nor grows with heat nor drowns with showers<sep>to this i witness call the fools of time<sep>which die for goodness who have lived for crime<sep>~<sep>weret aught to me i bore the canopy<sep>with my extern the outward honouring<sep>or laid great bases for eternity<sep>which proves more short than waste or ruining<sep>have i not seen dwellers on form and favour<sep>lose all and more by paying too much rent<sep>for compound sweet forgoing simple savour<sep>pitiful thrivers in their gazing spent<sep>no let me be obsequious in thy heart<sep>and take thou my oblation poor but free<sep>which is not mixed with seconds knows no art<sep>but mutual render only me for thee<sep>hence thou suborned informer a true soul<sep>when most impeached stands least in thy control<sep>~<sep>o thou my lovely boy who in thy power<sep>dost hold times fickle glass his fickle hour<sep>who hast by waning grown and therein showst<sep>thy lovers withering as thy sweet self growst<sep>if nature sovereign mistress over wrack<sep>as thou goest onwards still will pluck thee back<sep>she keeps thee to this purpose that her skill<sep>may time disgrace and wretched minutes kill<sep>yet fear her o thou minion of her pleasure<sep>she may detain but not still keep her treasure<sep>her audit though delayed answered must be<sep>and her quietus is to render thee<sep>~<sep>in the old age black was not counted fair<sep>or if it were it bore not beautys name<sep>but now is black beautys successive heir<sep>and beauty slandered with a bastard shame<sep>for since each hand hath put on natures power<sep>fairing the foul with arts false borrowed face<sep>sweet beauty hath no name no holy bower<sep>but is profaned if not lives in disgrace<sep>therefore my mistress eyes are raven black<sep>her eyes so suited and they mourners seem<sep>at such who not born fair no beauty lack<sep>slandering creation with a false esteem<sep>yet so they mourn becoming of their woe<sep>that every tongue says beauty should look so<sep>~<sep>how oft when thou my music music playst<sep>upon that blessed wood whose motion sounds<sep>with thy sweet fingers when thou gently swayst<sep>the wiry concord that mine ear confounds<sep>do i envy those jacks that nimble leap<sep>to kiss the tender inward of thy hand<sep>whilst my poor lips which should that harvest reap<sep>at the woods boldness by thee blushing stand<sep>to be so tickled they would change their state<sep>and situation with those dancing chips<sep>oer whom thy fingers walk with gentle gait<sep>making dead wood more blest than living lips<sep>since saucy jacks so happy are in this<sep>give them thy fingers me thy lips to kiss<sep>~<sep>th expense of spirit in a waste of shame<sep>is lust in action and till action lust<sep>is perjured murdrous bloody full of blame<sep>savage extreme rude cruel not to trust<sep>enjoyed no sooner but despised straight<sep>past reason hunted and no sooner had<sep>past reason hated as a swallowed bait<sep>on purpose laid to make the taker mad<sep>mad in pursuit and in possession so<sep>had having and in quest to have extreme<sep>a bliss in proof and proved a very woe<sep>before a joy proposed behind a dream<sep>all this the world well knows yet none knows well<sep>to shun the heaven that leads men to this hell<sep>~<sep>my mistress eyes are nothing like the sun<sep>coral is far more red than her lips red<sep>if snow be white why then her breasts are dun<sep>if hairs be wires black wires grow on her head<sep>i have seen roses damasked red and white<sep>but no such roses see i in her cheeks<sep>and in some perfumes is there more delight<sep>than in the breath that from my mistress reeks<sep>i love to hear her speak yet well i know<sep>that music hath a far more pleasing sound<sep>i grant i never saw a goddess go<sep>my mistress when she walks treads on the ground<sep>and yet by heaven i think my love as rare<sep>as any she belied with false compare<sep>~<sep>thou art as tyrannous so as thou art<sep>as those whose beauties proudly make them cruel<sep>for well thou knowst to my dear doting heart<sep>thou art the fairest and most precious jewel<sep>yet in good faith some say that thee behold<sep>thy face hath not the power to make love groan<sep>to say they err i dare not be so bold<sep>although i swear it to my self alone<sep>and to be sure that is not false i swear<sep>a thousand groans but thinking on thy face<sep>one on anothers neck do witness bear<sep>thy black is fairest in my judgments place<sep>in nothing art thou black save in thy deeds<sep>and thence this slander as i think proceeds<sep>~<sep>thine eyes i love and they as pitying me<sep>knowing thy heart torment me with disdain<sep>have put on black and loving mourners be<sep>looking with pretty ruth upon my pain<sep>and truly not the morning sun of heaven<sep>better becomes the grey cheeks of the east<sep>nor that full star that ushers in the even<sep>doth half that glory to the sober west<sep>as those two mourning eyes become thy face<sep>o let it then as well beseem thy heart<sep>to mourn for me since mourning doth thee grace<sep>and suit thy pity like in every part<sep>then will i swear beauty herself is black<sep>and all they foul that thy complexion lack<sep>~<sep>beshrew that heart that makes my heart to groan<sep>for that deep wound it gives my friend and me<sep>ist not enough to torture me alone<sep>but slave to slavery my sweetst friend must be<sep>me from my self thy cruel eye hath taken<sep>and my next self thou harder hast engrossed<sep>of him my self and thee i am forsaken<sep>a torment thrice threefold thus to be crossed<sep>prison my heart in thy steel bosoms ward<sep>but then my friends heart let my poor heart bail<sep>whoeer keeps me let my heart be his guard<sep>thou canst not then use rigour in my gaol<sep>and yet thou wilt for i being pent in thee<sep>perforce am thine and all that is in me<sep>~<sep>so now i have confessed that he is thine<sep>and i my self am mortgaged to thy will<sep>my self ill forfeit so that other mine<sep>thou wilt restore to be my comfort still<sep>but thou wilt not nor he will not be free<sep>for thou art covetous and he is kind<sep>he learned but suretylike to write for me<sep>under that bond that him as fist doth bind<sep>the statute of thy beauty thou wilt take<sep>thou usurer that putst forth all to use<sep>and sue a friend came debtor for my sake<sep>so him i lose through my unkind abuse<sep>him have i lost thou hast both him and me<sep>he pays the whole and yet am i not free<sep>~<sep>whoever hath her wish thou hast thy will<sep>and will to boot and will in overplus<sep>more than enough am i that vex thee still<sep>to thy sweet will making addition thus<sep>wilt thou whose will is large and spacious<sep>not once vouchsafe to hide my will in thine<sep>shall will in others seem right gracious<sep>and in my will no fair acceptance shine<sep>the sea all water yet receives rain still<sep>and in abundance addeth to his store<sep>so thou being rich in will add to thy will<sep>one will of mine to make thy large will more<sep>let no unkind no fair beseechers kill<sep>think all but one and me in that one will<sep>~<sep>if thy soul check thee that i come so near<sep>swear to thy blind soul that i was thy will<sep>and will thy soul knows is admitted there<sep>thus far for love my lovesuit sweet fulfil<sep>will will fulfil the treasure of thy love<sep>ay fill it full with wills and my will one<sep>in things of great receipt with case we prove<sep>among a number one is reckoned none<sep>then in the number let me pass untold<sep>though in thy stores account i one must be<sep>for nothing hold me so it please thee hold<sep>that nothing me a something sweet to thee<sep>make but my name thy love and love that still<sep>and then thou lovst me for my name is will<sep>~<sep>thou blind fool love what dost thou to mine eyes<sep>that they behold and see not what they see<sep>they know what beauty is see where it lies<sep>yet what the best is take the worst to be<sep>if eyes corrupt by overpartial looks<sep>be anchored in the bay where all men ride<sep>why of eyes falsehood hast thou forged hooks<sep>whereto the judgment of my heart is tied<sep>why should my heart think that a several plot<sep>which my heart knows the wide worlds common place<sep>or mine eyes seeing this say this is not<sep>to put fair truth upon so foul a face<sep>in things right true my heart and eyes have erred<sep>and to this false plague are they now transferred<sep>~<sep>when my love swears that she is made of truth<sep>i do believe her though i know she lies<sep>that she might think me some untutored youth<sep>unlearned in the worlds false subtleties<sep>thus vainly thinking that she thinks me young<sep>although she knows my days are past the best<sep>simply i credit her falsespeaking tongue<sep>on both sides thus is simple truth suppressed<sep>but wherefore says she not she is unjust<sep>and wherefore say not i that i am old<sep>o loves best habit is in seeming trust<sep>and age in love loves not to have years told<sep>therefore i lie with her and she with me<sep>and in our faults by lies we flattered be<sep>~<sep>o call not me to justify the wrong<sep>that thy unkindness lays upon my heart<sep>wound me not with thine eye but with thy tongue<sep>use power with power and slay me not by art<sep>tell me thou lovst elsewhere but in my sight<sep>dear heart forbear to glance thine eye aside<sep>what needst thou wound with cunning when thy might<sep>is more than my oerpressed defence can bide<sep>let me excuse thee ah my love well knows<sep>her pretty looks have been mine enemies<sep>and therefore from my face she turns my foes<sep>that they elsewhere might dart their injuries<sep>yet do not so but since i am near slain<sep>kill me outright with looks and rid my pain<sep>~<sep>be wise as thou art cruel do not press<sep>my tonguetied patience with too much disdain<sep>lest sorrow lend me words and words express<sep>the manner of my pitywanting pain<sep>if i might teach thee wit better it were<sep>though not to love yet love to tell me so<sep>as testy sick men when their deaths be near<sep>no news but health from their physicians know<sep>for if i should despair i should grow mad<sep>and in my madness might speak ill of thee<sep>now this illwresting world is grown so bad<sep>mad slanderers by mad ears believed be<sep>that i may not be so nor thou belied<sep>bear thine eyes straight though thy proud heart go wide<sep>~<sep>in faith i do not love thee with mine eyes<sep>for they in thee a thousand errors note<sep>but tis my heart that loves what they despise<sep>who in despite of view is pleased to dote<sep>nor are mine cars with thy tongues tune delighted<sep>nor tender feeling to base touches prone<sep>nor taste nor smell desire to be invited<sep>to any sensual feast with thee alone<sep>but my five wits nor my five senses can<sep>dissuade one foolish heart from serving thee<sep>who leaves unswayed the likeness of a man<sep>thy proud hearts slave and vassal wretch to be<sep>only my plague thus far i count my gain<sep>that she that makes me sin awards me pain<sep>~<sep>love is my sin and thy dear virtue hate<sep>hate of my sin grounded on sinful loving<sep>o but with mine compare thou thine own state<sep>and thou shalt find it merits not reproving<sep>or if it do not from those lips of thine<sep>that have profaned their scarlet ornaments<sep>and sealed false bonds of love as oft as mine<sep>robbed others beds revenues of their rents<sep>be it lawful i love thee as thou lovst those<sep>whom thine eyes woo as mine importune thee<sep>root pity in thy heart that when it grows<sep>thy pity may deserve to pitied be<sep>if thou dost seek to have what thou dost hide<sep>by selfexample mayst thou be denied<sep>~<sep>lo as a careful huswife runs to catch<sep>one of her feathered creatures broke away<sep>sets down her babe and makes all swift dispatch<sep>in pursuit of the thing she would have stay<sep>whilst her neglected child holds her in chase<sep>cries to catch her whose busy care is bent<sep>to follow that which flies before her face<sep>not prizing her poor infants discontent<sep>so runst thou after that which flies from thee<sep>whilst i thy babe chase thee afar behind<sep>but if thou catch thy hope turn back to me<sep>and play the mothers part kiss me be kind<sep>so will i pray that thou mayst have thy will<sep>if thou turn back and my loud crying still<sep>~<sep>two loves i have of comfort and despair<sep>which like two spirits do suggest me still<sep>the better angel is a man right fair<sep>the worser spirit a woman coloured ill<sep>to win me soon to hell my female evil<sep>tempteth my better angel from my side<sep>and would corrupt my saint to be a devil<sep>wooing his purity with her foul pride<sep>and whether that my angel be turned fiend<sep>suspect i may yet not directly tell<sep>but being both from me both to each friend<sep>i guess one angel in anothers hell<sep>yet this shall i neer know but live in doubt<sep>till my bad angel fire my good one out<sep>~<sep>those lips that loves own hand did make<sep>breathed forth the sound that said i hate<sep>to me that languished for her sake<sep>but when she saw my woeful state<sep>straight in her heart did mercy come<sep>chiding that tongue that ever sweet<sep>was used in giving gentle doom<sep>and taught it thus anew to greet<sep>i hate she altered with an end<sep>that followed it as gentle day<sep>doth follow night who like a fiend<sep>from heaven to hell is flown away<sep>i hate from hate away she threw<sep>and saved my life saying not you<sep>~<sep>poor soul the centre of my sinful earth<sep>my sinful earth these rebel powers array<sep>why dost thou pine within and suffer dearth<sep>painting thy outward walls so costly gay<sep>why so large cost having so short a lease<sep>dost thou upon thy fading mansion spend<sep>shall worms inheritors of this excess<sep>eat up thy charge is this thy bodys end<sep>then soul live thou upon thy servants loss<sep>and let that pine to aggravate thy store<sep>buy terms divine in selling hours of dross<sep>within be fed without be rich no more<sep>so shall thou feed on death that feeds on men<sep>and death once dead theres no more dying then<sep>~<sep>my love is as a fever longing still<sep>for that which longer nurseth the disease<sep>feeding on that which doth preserve the ill<sep>th uncertain sickly appetite to please<sep>my reason the physician to my love<sep>angry that his prescriptions are not kept<sep>hath left me and i desperate now approve<sep>desire is death which physic did except<sep>past cure i am now reason is past care<sep>and franticmad with evermore unrest<sep>my thoughts and my discourse as mad mens are<sep>at random from the truth vainly expressed<sep>for i have sworn thee fair and thought thee bright<sep>who art as black as hell as dark as night<sep>~<sep>o me what eyes hath love put in my head<sep>which have no correspondence with true sight<sep>or if they have where is my judgment fled<sep>that censures falsely what they see aright<sep>if that be fair whereon my false eyes dote<sep>what means the world to say it is not so<sep>if it be not then love doth well denote<sep>loves eye is not so true as all mens no<sep>how can it o how can loves eye be true<sep>that is so vexed with watching and with tears<sep>no marvel then though i mistake my view<sep>the sun it self sees not till heaven clears<sep>o cunning love with tears thou keepst me blind<sep>lest eyes wellseeing thy foul faults should find<sep>~<sep>canst thou o cruel say i love thee not<sep>when i against my self with thee partake<sep>do i not think on thee when i forgot<sep>am of my self alltyrant for thy sake<sep>who hateth thee that i do call my friend<sep>on whom frownst thou that i do fawn upon<sep>nay if thou lourst on me do i not spend<sep>revenge upon my self with present moan<sep>what merit do i in my self respect<sep>that is so proud thy service to despise<sep>when all my best doth worship thy defect<sep>commanded by the motion of thine eyes<sep>but love hate on for now i know thy mind<sep>those that can see thou lovst and i am blind<sep>~<sep>o from what power hast thou this powerful might<sep>with insufficiency my heart to sway<sep>to make me give the lie to my true sight<sep>and swear that brightness doth not grace the day<sep>whence hast thou this becoming of things ill<sep>that in the very refuse of thy deeds<sep>there is such strength and warrantise of skill<sep>that in my mind thy worst all best exceeds<sep>who taught thee how to make me love thee more<sep>the more i hear and see just cause of hate<sep>o though i love what others do abhor<sep>with others thou shouldst not abhor my state<sep>if thy unworthiness raised love in me<sep>more worthy i to be beloved of thee<sep>~<sep>love is too young to know what conscience is<sep>yet who knows not conscience is born of love<sep>then gentle cheater urge not my amiss<sep>lest guilty of my faults thy sweet self prove<sep>for thou betraying me i do betray<sep>my nobler part to my gross bodys treason<sep>my soul doth tell my body that he may<sep>triumph in love flesh stays no farther reason<sep>but rising at thy name doth point out thee<sep>as his triumphant prize proud of this pride<sep>he is contented thy poor drudge to be<sep>to stand in thy affairs fall by thy side<sep>no want of conscience hold it that i call<sep>her love for whose dear love i rise and fall<sep>~<sep>in loving thee thou knowst i am forsworn<sep>but thou art twice forsworn to me love swearing<sep>in act thy bedvow broke and new faith torn<sep>in vowing new hate after new love bearing<sep>but why of two oaths breach do i accuse thee<sep>when i break twenty i am perjured most<sep>for all my vows are oaths but to misuse thee<sep>and all my honest faith in thee is lost<sep>for i have sworn deep oaths of thy deep kindness<sep>oaths of thy love thy truth thy constancy<sep>and to enlighten thee gave eyes to blindness<sep>or made them swear against the thing they see<sep>for i have sworn thee fair more perjured i<sep>to swear against the truth so foul a be<sep>~<sep>cupid laid by his brand and fell asleep<sep>a maid of dians this advantage found<sep>and his lovekindling fire did quickly steep<sep>in a cold valleyfountain of that ground<sep>which borrowed from this holy fire of love<sep>a dateless lively heat still to endure<sep>and grew a seeting bath which yet men prove<sep>against strange maladies a sovereign cure<sep>but at my mistress eye loves brand newfired<sep>the boy for trial needs would touch my breast<sep>i sick withal the help of bath desired<sep>and thither hied a sad distempered guest<sep>but found no cure the bath for my help lies<sep>where cupid got new fire my mistress eyes<sep>~<sep>the little lovegod lying once asleep<sep>laid by his side his heartinflaming brand<sep>whilst many nymphs that vowed chaste life to keep<sep>came tripping by but in her maiden hand<sep>the fairest votary took up that fire<sep>which many legions of true hearts had warmed<sep>and so the general of hot desire<sep>was sleeping by a virgin hand disarmed<sep>this brand she quenched in a cool well by<sep>which from loves fire took heat perpetual<sep>growing a bath and healthful remedy<sep>for men discased but i my mistress thrall<sep>came there for cure and this by that i prove<sep>loves fire heats water water cools not love
